image.altText: A small submarine appearing to dive downwards into the ocean.

items.synopsis: The US Coast Guard says underwater noises have been detected by an aircraft in the search for the missing submersible.

title.children: US Coast Guard says underwater noises detected in search for missing submersible

image.altText: A picture of a sign which says Titanic survey expedition.

items.synopsis: As the search continues for the missing Titan submersible, questions are being raised around the vessel's safety and what could have possibly gone wrong.

title.children: Was the Titan safe? Questions raised over what went wrong with the missing submersible

image.altText: A kangaroo stands in front of two soccer boots, one made by Nike and the other by Puma.

items.synopsis: Commercial kangaroo shooters are regulated under a national code that's supposed to protect animal welfare, but activists say what happens in rural Australia at night can be in breach of it, putting the industry under threat.

title.children: Why big brands in the US are ditching kangaroo leather

image.altText: a woman walking a long a street smiling

items.synopsis: The delivery of the report into whether Gladys Berejiklian breached public trust faced lengthy delays and comes more than two-and-a-half years ago after the corruption watchdog's hearings.

title.children: Date set for release of corruption findings into former NSW premier Gladys Berejiklian

image.altText: A frozen bubble, with icicle underneath it.

items.synopsis: Temperatures across NSW plummeted overnight. It's now been confirmed many towns have experienced their coldest morning on record.

title.children: Records broken as parts of country's south-east freezes through sub-zero temperatures overnight

image.altText: A composite image showing a young man, a woman and an older man.

items.synopsis: Confidentiality laws have long kept the plight of people whose finances are controlled by the state hidden from view, but there are growing calls for the agencies these vulnerable people depend on to be subjected to greater scrutiny.

title.children: Can public trustees' controversial business model withstand the spotlight?

image.altText: Nicola Gobbo gazing into the distance with her arms folded

items.synopsis: The special investigator appointed to build criminal cases against disgraced barrister Nicola Gobbo and police officers who recruited her as a confidential source has attacked the director of public prosecutions for refusing to approve criminal charges against them.

title.children: Former High Court judge asked to assess potential Lawyer X charges lashes the state's chief prosecutor

image.altText: Ice

items.synopsis: A Tasmanian inquiry hears disturbing accounts of children being injected and given ice by parents wanting them to commit crimes.

title.children: 'You poor little thing': Parents injecting kids with ice to commit crimes, inquiry hears

image.altText: Lea Russ lying in a hospital bed wearing a blue surgical mask, with her arm hooked up to an IV.

items.synopsis: Patients who need to see a GP urgently are increasingly waiting more than 24 hours to be seen. But they may not know that general practices are meant to offer emergency bookings.

title.children: Getting an urgent GP appointment can be hard, but a little-known rule means it shouldn't be

image.altText: A large sign reading Port Pirie Regional Health Service outside a collection of buildings.

items.synopsis: A nursing union calls for 24/7 security guards after five medical staff were injured by a man suffering a psychotic episode at a South Australian hospital.

title.children: Two nurses and three doctors attacked by patient in 'terrifying incident' at regional hospital

image.altText: Sydney gay hate murders

items.synopsis: Legal correspondence about an inquiry into gay hate crimes reveals NSW Police provided material more than a year late and seemingly found old crime scene photographs "by chance".

title.children: Police found crime scene photos 'by chance' 40 years after toilet block death, letters show

image.altText: A smiling young woman on a carousel.

items.synopsis: Niamh Maye was 18 years old when she disappeared from a country town in NSW in 2002. With her family still desperate for answers, police are hoping a large reward will encourage someone to come forward.

title.children: On the day Niamh would have turned 40, police offer $250k in push to solve decades-old mystery

image.altText: A selfie of a woman in a Western Bulldogs top.

items.synopsis: A woman who fatally stabbed her mother in a drunken rage at their home in Adelaide's north could be eligible for parole in less than two years after a judge found there were "exceptional circumstances".

title.children: Daughter jailed for fatally stabbing mother in Adelaide's north

image.altText: Joe Biden sits at a desk while Xi Jinping can be seen on a TV screen.

items.synopsis: US President Joe Biden refers to Xi Jinping as a "dictator" during a fundraiser in California, also saying his Chinese counterpart was embarrassed when a balloon "full of spy equipment" blew into United States airspace earlier this year.

title.children: Biden calls Xi a dictator, claims he was embarrassed by 'spy' balloon incident

image.altText: People protest outside a building

items.synopsis: The announcement follows a similar decision by US aluminium giant Alcoa, which vowed to not mine an 8,400-hectare zone around Dwellingup that environmentalists call "greenwashing".

title.children: Rio Tinto bows to community pressure, withdraws mining application for south-west forest

image.altText: A middle-aged man in jeans and a jacket sits in a chair and smiles. In front is a table with Titanic Expedition written on it

items.synopsis: A renowned Titanic expert, a world-record-holding adventurer, two members of one of Pakistan's wealthiest families and the CEO of the company leading an expedition to the world's most famous shipwreck are facing critical danger aboard a small submersible that has gone missing in the Atlantic Ocean.

title.children: A Titanic expert, an adventurer, a father and his son and a CEO: These are the people on the missing submersible

image.altText: Yunupingu with Gumatj children at Garma in 2019.

items.synopsis: Late Gumatj clan leader Yunupingu won a historic legal battle that could have significant implications for compensation claims across Australia. The Commonwealth is now appealing.

title.children: Commonwealth lodges High Court challenge to landmark $700 million native title compensation claim

image.altText: A rainbow-coloured sign advertising the cancellation of an event.

items.synopsis: When organisers first convinced traditionally conservative parts of the country to host a Pride ball, it was celebrated as a win for inclusion. Now thriving, these events are increasingly facing a new and sinister threat.

title.children: Far right groups and conspiracy theorists forcing shutdowns of pride events in growing trend

image.altText: A tank is seen firing a large ball of fire.

items.synopsis: Russia has struck military and infrastructure targets in Ukraine's capital and across other parts of the country, including western areas far from the front lines, according to Kyiv.

title.children: Russian air strikes hit Kyiv, other cities as Ukraine reports progress in counteroffensive

image.altText: Signage at a Telstra store in Sydney.

items.synopsis: Chocolate maker Ernest Hillier enters administration and workers are stood down. TPG shares drop as a deal with Telstra remains blocked. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Telstra-TPG regional network deal blocked, Ernest Hillier collapses, ASX in the red

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Investment bank UBS has conducted a survey of 1,000 Australians, which it says confirms its view that there will be a mid-year slowdown. The survey, conducted over the second half of May, shows a decline in the financial outlook from Australian consumers, as a bigger portion of their spending went essentials like rent and utilities. "Middle-income households are now showing clear signs that the transmission of pain  from the rate hiking cycle (which began over a year ago) is now hitting hard," UBS strategists wrote. "…Consumers in 'mortgage belt' Australia are telling us that they expect to sharply reduce  their spending on 'fun' categories, such as entertainment, recreation, eating out, takeaway food, and international travel." The survey also found evidence of a divide: "Many low-income consumers have now run out of savings, and are increasingly having  to borrow from others, or sell their belongings, to fund daily spending. "By contrast, high  income consumers are in a favourable position with ample cash balances and the ability  to draw down on investments." As a result, UBS has changed its rating or earnings estimates for a number of consumer stocks, and some of those are in the red today: JB Hi-Fi (-2.1%) Harvey Norman (-2%) Super Retail Group (-2%) Premier Investments (-3.9%)
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Cracks emerging for Aussie consumers: UBS

children.content: Investment bank
UBS
has conducted a survey of 1,000 Australians, which it says confirms its view that there will be a mid-year slowdown.
The survey, conducted over the second half of May, shows a decline in the financial outlook from Australian consumers, as a
bigger portion of their spending went essentials like rent and utilities
"Middle-income households are now showing clear signs that the transmission of pain  from the rate hiking cycle (which began over a year ago) is now hitting hard," UBS strategists wrote.
"…Consumers in 'mortgage belt' Australia are telling us that they
expect to sharply reduce  their spending on 'fun' categories
, such as entertainment, recreation, eating out, takeaway food, and international travel."
The survey also found evidence of a divide:
"Many low-income consumers have now run out of savings, and are increasingly having  to borrow from others, or sell their belongings, to fund daily spending.
"By contrast, high  income consumers are in a favourable position with ample cash balances and the ability  to draw down on investments."
Households are savings less
(UBS Evidence Lab survey)
As a result, UBS has changed its rating or earnings estimates for a number of consumer stocks, and some of those are in the red today:
JB Hi-Fi (-2.1%)
Harvey Norman (-2%)
Super Retail Group (-2%)
Premier Investments (-3.9%)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Grok Ventures, the private investment firm of billionaire Mike Cannon-Brookes, has reduced its stake in AGL. However, Grok remains the biggest shareholder of the energy giant ,and AGL will still be the largest holding in Grok's portfolio. In announcing the sale of a "small parcel of shares", Grok 'applauded' moves by AGL to plan moves towards electrification and away from gas and coal. "We have decided to rebalance our portfolio to enable us to pursue other exciting climate technology and renewable energy investments ," Grok chief executive Jeremy Kwong-Law wrote. "We continue to implore AGL to increase its decarbonisation ambitions. "In particular, firm up closure dates for Bayswater and Loy Yang A which are consistent with a 1.5 degree [warming] scenario… "We look forward to continuing to work constructively with the board and management to tackle the huge mission of decarbonsiation and electrification." AGL shares have fallen around 0.4 per cent so far today, which is a better performance than the broader energy sector this session.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Cannon-Brookes' Grok Ventures reduces stake in AGL

children.content: Grok Ventures
, the private investment firm of billionaire Mike Cannon-Brookes, has reduced its stake in
AGL
However,
Grok remains the biggest shareholder of the energy giant
,and AGL will still be the largest holding in Grok's portfolio.
In announcing the sale of a "small parcel of shares", Grok 'applauded' moves by AGL to plan moves towards electrification and away from gas and coal.
"We have decided to rebalance our portfolio
to enable us to pursue other exciting climate technology and renewable energy investments
," Grok chief executive Jeremy Kwong-Law wrote.
"We continue to implore AGL to increase its decarbonisation ambitions.
"In particular, firm up closure dates for Bayswater and Loy Yang A which are consistent with a 1.5 degree [warming] scenario…
"We look forward to continuing to work constructively with the board and management to tackle the huge mission of decarbonsiation and electrification."
AGL shares have fallen around 0.4 per cent so far today, which is a better performance than the broader energy sector this session.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: First the Fantales, now this. Chocolate company Ernest Hillier has gone into voluntary administration — i t runs the Ernest Hillier and Newman’s brands of chocolate. Workers at its Melbourne plant have been stood down. In a statement it was announced the company had appointed WLP Restructuring Partners, Alan Walker and Glenn Livingstone as voluntary administrators to the company which owns and manufactures Ernest Hillier Chocolates, one of Australia’s’ oldest chocolate brands. Company directors blamed "rising raw materials and shipping costs significantly impact(ing) margins" for the decline of the sweet maker. The chocolates are in major supermarket chains Woolworths, Coles, and Aldi and the company also produces 'white-label' chocolates for other providers. So-called 'white label' manufacturing is where you make something on behalf of another company, who then put their own brand on it. Ernest Hillier has a factory in Coburg, Melbourne and the administrators are seeking "urgent expressions of interest from parties that could recapitalise or acquire the business" and its assets and brands. WLP Restructuring Partner, Alan Walker, said it was a tough situation. “It’s unfortunate that such a storied chocolate manufacturer has encountered distress amid rising operating costs, but we are working with all stakeholders to do everything possible to save this iconic brand.” “We are working closely with all affected parties as we move with urgency to understand the business’s affairs and find a suitable buyer or investor. While this process is underway, we have had to make the unfortunate decision to cease manufacturing activity and stand down employees at this stage. However, this dedicated workforce is available and keen to restart production.” “The Company operates a significant manufacturing facility in Coburg, and the Ernest Hillier and Newman’s brands have featured on the shelves of Australia’s supermarkets for many years. We expect these supply agreements, alongside its relationships with large multi-national food and beverage providers, may appeal to potential suitors.” The first statutory meeting of creditors will be held on 30 June 2023. The news comes the day after it was revealed that iconic treat Fantales would no longer be made, a victim of declining popularity and old machinery requiring big investments to keep running.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Chocolate maker Ernest Hillier collapses, staff stood down

featuredLink.title: 'What do we put in the lolly jar now?': End of an era as Nestlé calls a wrap on Fantales

children.content: First the Fantales, now this.
Chocolate company Ernest Hillier has gone into voluntary administration — i
t runs the
Ernest Hillier and Newman’s brands of chocolate.
Workers at its Melbourne plant have been stood down

In a statement it was announced the company had appointed WLP Restructuring Partners, Alan Walker and Glenn Livingstone as voluntary administrators to the company which owns and manufactures Ernest Hillier Chocolates, one of Australia’s’ oldest chocolate brands.
Company directors blamed "rising raw materials and shipping costs significantly impact(ing) margins" for the decline of the sweet maker.
Ernest Hillier chocolates
(Ernest Hillier )
The chocolates are in
major supermarket chains
Woolworths, Coles, and Aldi and the company
also produces 'white-label' chocolates
for other providers.
So-called 'white label' manufacturing is where you make something on behalf of another company, who then put their own brand on it.
Ernest Hillier has a factory in Coburg, Melbourne
and the administrators are seeking "urgent expressions of interest from parties that could recapitalise or acquire the business" and its assets and brands.
WLP Restructuring Partner, Alan Walker, said it was a tough situation.

“It’s unfortunate that such a storied chocolate manufacturer has encountered distress amid rising operating costs, but we are working with all stakeholders to do everything possible to save this iconic brand.”

“We are working closely with all affected parties as we move with urgency to understand the business’s affairs and find a suitable buyer or investor. While this process is underway, we have had to make the unfortunate decision to cease manufacturing activity and stand down employees at this stage. However, this dedicated workforce is available and keen to restart production.”

“The Company operates a significant manufacturing facility in Coburg, and the Ernest Hillier and Newman’s brands have featured on the shelves of Australia’s supermarkets for many years. We expect these supply agreements, alongside its relationships with large multi-national food and beverage providers, may appeal to potential suitors.”
The first statutory
meeting of creditors will be held on 30 June
The news comes the day after it was revealed that iconic treat Fantales would no longer be made, a victim of declining popularity and old machinery requiring big investments to keep running.

title.children: Scientists created 'synthetic embryos' without sperm or eggs. What are the legal and ethical implications?

image.altText: A group of mourners with their arms around each other crying.

title.children: Palestinian gunmen kill four Israelis in response to deadly army raid

image.altText: Carcasses of two fin whales are tied to a whaling ship as it anchors near a processing plant.

title.children: Iceland suspends whale hunting over animal welfare concerns

image.altText: A group of rugby league players look dejected after conceding a try
